00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
but to help right now.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
So we tried to come up with a way,

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
as a group, to have a kind of design SWAT team.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
And that was the mission that we came up with.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
KA: Were you conscious of suddenly --

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:29.958
as a designer whose work is all about fulfilling wants --

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:34.958
suddenly fulfilling needs?

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
DR: Well what I was aware of was,

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
there was this overwhelming need to act now.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:46.958
And we were asked to participate in a few projects before this.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:52.958
There was a school, PS 234, that had been evacuated down at Ground Zero.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
They moved to an abandoned school.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
We took about 20 or 30 architects and designers and artists,

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and over four days -- it was like this urban barn-raising --

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
to renovate it, and everyone wanted to help.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
It was just extraordinary.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
Tom Otterness contributed, Maira Kalman contributed

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:12.958
and it became this cathartic experience for us.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
KA: And that was done, effectively,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
by October 8 or something?

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
DR: Yeah.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
KA: Obviously, what you faced in trying to do something

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
as substantial as this project -- and this is only one of four

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
that you've designed to surround the site --

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:34.958
you must have run up against the incredibly byzantine,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:39.958
entrenched bureaucracy and powers that be

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
in New York real estate and New York politics.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
DR: Well, it's a funny thing.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
We finished PS 234, and had dinner with a small group.

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:51.958
I was actually asked to be a committee chair on an AIA committee to rebuild.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
And I sat in on several meetings.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:57.958
And there were the most circuitous grand plans

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:02.958
that had to do with long-term infrastructure and rebuilding the entire city.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:08.958
And the fact is that there were immediate wounds and needs that needed to be filled,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
and there was talk about inclusion and wanting it to be an inclusive process.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And it wasn't an inclusive group.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:14.958
So we said, what is --

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
KA: It was not an inclusive group?

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
DR: It was not an inclusive group.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
It was predominantly a white, rich, corporate group

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
that was not representative of the city.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
KA: Shocking.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
DR: Yeah, surprising.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:34.958
So Rick and Liz and Kevin and I came up with the idea.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
The city actually approached us.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
We first approached the city about Pier 94.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
We saw how PS 234 worked.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
The families -- the victims of the families --

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:47.958
were going to this pier that was incredibly dehumanizing.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
KA: On the Hudson River?

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
DR: Yeah. And the city actually -- through Tim Zagat initially,

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:55.958
and then through Christyne Nicholas, then we got to Giuliani --

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
said, "You know we don't want to do anything with Pier 94 right now,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
but we have an observation platform for the families down at Ground Zero

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:05.958
that we'd like to be a more dignified experience for the families,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
and a way to protect it from the weather."

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:11.958
So I went down there with Rick and Liz and Kevin,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:16.958
and I've got to say, it was the most moving experience of my life.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:20.958
It was devastating to see the simple plywood platform with a rail around it,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
where the families of the victims had left notes to them.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:27.958
And there was no mediation between us and the experience.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
There was no filter.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:34.958
And I remembered on September 11th, on 14th Street,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
the roof of our building -- we can see the World Trade Towers prominently --

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and I saw the first building collapse from a conference room

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
on the eighth floor on a TV that we had set up.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
And then everyone was up on the roof, so I ran up there.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
And it was amazing how much harder it was

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:56.958
to believe in real life than it was on TV.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
There was something about the comfort of the filter

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
and how much information was between us and the experience.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
So seeing this in a very simple,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
dignified way was a very powerful experience.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
So we went back to the city and said

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
we're not particularly interested in the upgrade of this as a VIP platform,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:17.958
but we've spent some time down there.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:22.958
At the same time the city had this need.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
They were looking for a solution

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
to deal with 30 or 40 thousand people a day

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
who were going down there, that had nowhere to go.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And there was no way to deal with the traffic around the site.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
So dealing with it is just an immediate master plan.

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
There was a way -- there had to be a way --

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
to get people to move around the site.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
KA: But then you've got to figure out a way --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:47.958
we will skip over the insanely tedious process of getting permits

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
and getting everybody on board -- but simply funding this thing.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
It looks like a fairly simple thing,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
but this was a half a million dollar project?

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
DR: Well, we knew that if it wasn't privately funded,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
it wasn't going to happen.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
And we also, frankly, knew that if it didn't happen

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
by the end of the Giuliani administration,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
then everyone who we were dealing with at the DOT

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
and the Police Department and all of the --

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
we were meeting with 20 or 30 people with the city at a time,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
and it was set up by the Office of Emergency Management.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
This incredible act on their part, because they really wanted this,

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and they sensed that this needed to happen.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
KA: And there was therefore this ticking clock,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
because Giuliani was obviously out three months after that.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
DR: Yeah. So the first thing we had to do was find a way to get this --

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:36.958
we had to work with the families of the victims,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
through the city, to make sure that they knew this was happening.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Because this didn't want to be a surprise.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:45.958
And we also had to be as under the radar screen as we could be in New York,

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:48.958
because the key was not raising a lot of objection

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and sort of working as quietly as possible.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
We came up with the idea of setting up a foundation,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:11:01.958
mainly because when we found a contractor who would build this,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:07.958
he would not agree to do this, even if we would pay him the money.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:08.958
There needed to be a foundation in place.

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:13.958
So we came up with a foundation, and actually what happened was

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
one major developer in New York --

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
KA: Who shall remain nameless, I guess?

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
DR: Yeah. His initials are JS, and he owns Rockefeller Center,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
if that helps anyone -- volunteered to help.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
And we met with him.

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:32.958
The prices from the contractors were between five to 700,000 dollars.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
And Atlantic-Heydt, who's the largest scaffolding contractor in the country,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
volunteered to do it at cost.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
So this developer said, "You know what, we'll underwrite the entire expense."

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And we said, "That's incredible!"

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And I think this was the 21st,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
and we knew this had to be built and up by the 28th.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:53.958
And we had to start construction the next day.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:57.958
We had a meeting that evening with his contractor of choice,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:01.958
and the contractor showed up with the drawings of the platform

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
about half the size that we had drawn it.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
KA: Sort of like the Spinal Tap scene where you get

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
the tiny little Stonehenge, I guess?

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:11.958
(Laughter)

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
DR: In fact, it was as if this was going to be window-washing scaffolding.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.958
There was no sense of the fact that this is next to Saint Paul --

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:22.958
that this is really a place that needs to be kind of dignified,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
and a place to reflect and remember.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And I've got to say that we spent a lot of time

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
in putting this together, watching the crowds that gathered at Saint Paul --

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
which is just to the right -- and moving around the site.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:36.958
And I live down there, so we spent a lot of time looking at the need.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:40.958
And I think people were amazed at two things --

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
I think they were amazed at the destruction,

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
but I think there was a sense of disbelief

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:49.958
about the heroics of New Yorkers that I found very moving.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Just the sort of everyday heroics of New Yorkers.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:57.958
So we were in this meeting and the contractor literally said,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
"I'm going to lock the door, because this developer

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:03.958
will not agree to have you leave till you've signed off on this."

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
And we said, "Well, this is half the size,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:09.958
it doesn't have any of the design features

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
that have been agreed upon by everyone -- everyone in the city.

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:15.958
We'd have to go back to the beginning to do this."

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And I convinced him that we should leave the room

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:22.958
with the agreement to build it as designed.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
The next day I got an email from the developer

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:28.958
saying that he was withdrawing all funding.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:33.958
So we didn't know what to do,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
but we decided to cast a very wide net.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
We emailed out letters to as many people as we could --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:42.958
several people in the audience here -- who were very helpful.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
KA: There was no thought of abandoning ship at that point?

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:49.958
DR: No. In fact I told the contractor to go ahead.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
He had already ordered materials based on my go-ahead.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
We knew that one way or another this was going to happen.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:59.958
And we just felt it had to happen.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:04.958
KA: You were funding it yourself and with contributions and this foundation.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:10.958
Richard, I think very correctly,

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
made the point at the beginning --

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
before all the chair designers came out --

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:21.958
about the history of chair designers imposing aesthetic solutions

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:25.958
on this kind of universal, banal, common problem of sitting.

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:29.958
It seems to me with this,

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
that it was the opposite of that.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:35.958
This was an unprecedented, singular design problem.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
DR: Well here's the issue:

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
we knew that this was not in the sense of --

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:46.958
we think about the site, and think about the need for a memorial.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:49.958
It was important that this not be categorized as a memorial.

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:55.958
That this was a place for people to reflect, to remember --

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
a kind of quiet place.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
So it led us to using design solutions

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
that created as few filters between the viewer --

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
as we said about the families' platform -- and the experience as possible.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
It's all incredibly humble material.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
It's scaffolding and plywood.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:19.958
And it allows -- by sort of the procession of the movement,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
up by Saint Paul's and down the other side --

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.958
it gives you about 300 feet to go up 13 feet from the ground

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
to where you get the 360 degree view.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:37.958
But the design was driven by a need to be quick, cheap, safe, respectful, flexible.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
One of the other things is this is designed to be moveable.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Because when we looked at the four platforms around the site,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
one of which is an upgrade of the families' platform,

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
we knew that these had to be moveable

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
to respond to changing conditions,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:57.958
and the changing definition of what Ground Zero is.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.958
KA: Your work -- I mean, we've talked about this before --

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:06.958
a lot of your work, I think, is informed by your belief in, or your focus on

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:10.958
the temporariness of all things and the evanescence of things,

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:14.958
and a kind of "Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow we die,"

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
sort of sense of existence.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:22.958
This is clearly not a work for the ages.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
You know, a couple of years this thing isn't going to be here.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Did that require, as an architect,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
a new way of thinking about what you were doing?

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:36.958
To think of it as this purely temporary installation?

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
DR: No, I don't think so.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:42.958
I think this is, obviously, substantially different

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
from anything we'd ever thought about doing before, just by the nature of it.

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:52.958
Where it overlaps with thoughts about our work in general is,

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:56.958
number one -- the notion of collaboration as a sort of way to get things done.

00:16:56.958 --> 00:17:01.958
And Kevin Kennon, Rick Scofidio, Liz Diller

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:06.958
and all the people within the city --

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:11.958
Norman Lear, who I spoke to four hours before our deadline for funding,

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:15.958
offered to give us a bridge loan to help us get through it.

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
So the notion of collaboration --

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
I think this reinforces how important that is.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.958
And in terms of the temporary nature of it,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
our goal was not to create something

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
that would be there longer than it needed to be.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:34.958
I think what we were most interested in was promoting a kind of dialogue

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:38.958
that we felt may not have been happening enough in this city,

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
about what's really happening there.

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:47.958
And a day or two before it opened was Giuliani's farewell address,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
where he proposed the idea of all of Ground Zero being a memorial.

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
Which was very controversial, but it resonated with a lot of people.

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:58.958
And I think regardless of what the position is about how

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:02.958
this sacred piece of land is to be used,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:07.958
having it come out of actually seeing it in a real encounter,

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
I think makes it a more powerful dialogue.

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
And that's what we were interested in.

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
So that, very much, is in the realm of things

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:16.958
I've been interested in before.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:19.958
KA: It seems to me, among other things, a lovely piece of civic infrastructure.

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:23.958
It enables that conversation to get serious.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:26.958
And six months after the fact --

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and only a few months away from the site being cleaned --

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
we are very quickly, now, getting to the point

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:37.958
where those conversations about what should go there are getting serious.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:42.958
Do you have -- having been as physically involved in the site

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:44.958
as you have been doing this project -- have any ideas about

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:46.958
what should or shouldn't be done?

00:18:46.958 --> 00:18:51.958
DR: Well, I think one thing that shouldn't be done is evaluate --

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:57.958
I think right now the discussion is a very closed discussion on the master plan.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:02.958
The Protetch Gallery recently had a show on ideas for buildings,

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:06.958
which had some sort of inventive ideas of buildings.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
KA: But it had some really terrible ideas.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:12.958
DR: And it also felt a little bit like a kind of competition of ideas,

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:17.958
where I think the focus of ideas should be on master planning and uses.

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
And I think there should be a broader -- which there's starting to be --

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:22.958
the dialogue is really opening up to,

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
what does this site really want to be?

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:28.958
And I truly believe until the issue of memorial is sorted out,

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:31.958
that it's going to be very hard to have an intelligent discussion.

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:36.958
There's a few discussions right now that I think are very positive,

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:40.958
about depressing the West Side Highway and connecting this over,

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
so that there's one uninterrupted piece of land.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:45.958
KA: Well, I think that's interesting.

00:19:45.958 --> 00:19:48.958
And it gets to another issue that was probably inappropriate

00:19:48.958 --> 00:19:50.958
to discuss six months ago, but perhaps isn't now,

00:19:50.958 --> 00:19:56.958
which is, not many of us love the World Trade Center as a piece of architecture,

00:19:56.958 --> 00:20:00.958
as what it had done to this city and that huge plaza.

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:03.958
Is this an opportunity, is the silver lining --

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
a silver lining, here -- to rebuild

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:09.958
some more traditional city grid, or not?

00:20:09.958 --> 00:20:11.958
DR: I think there's a real opportunity to engage

00:20:11.958 --> 00:20:13.958
in a discussion of why we live in cities.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.958
And why do we live in places where such dissimilar people

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:19.958
collide up against us each day?

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:24.958
I don't think it has much to do with 50 or 60 or 70 or 80 thousand new office spaces,

00:20:24.958 --> 00:20:26.958
regardless of what the number is.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:30.958
So yeah, I think there is a chance to re-look at how we think about cities.

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:36.958
And in fact, there's a proposal on the table now for building number seven.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:38.958
KA: Which was the building just north of the Towers?

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:40.958
DR: Right, which the towers fell into.

00:20:40.958 --> 00:20:45.958
And the reason that's been held up is essentially by community outrage

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:47.958
that they're not re-opening the street

00:20:47.958 --> 00:20:49.958
to connect that back to the rest of the city.

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:52.958
I think a public dialogue -- I think, you know,

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:56.958
I'd like to see an international competition,

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:59.958
and a call for ideas for uses.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:01.958
KA: Whether it's arts, whether it's housing,

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:03.958
whether it's what amount of shopping?

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:05.958
DR: Right. And we're looking for other things.

00:21:05.958 --> 00:21:08.958
This small foundation we put together is looking for other ways to help.

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:12.958
Including taking a small piece adjacent to the site

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:16.958
and inviting 10 architects who currently don't have a voice

00:21:16.958 --> 00:21:18.958
in New York to do artist housing.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:20.958
And find other ways to encourage the discussion

00:21:20.958 --> 00:21:23.958
to be against sort of monolithic, single solutions,

00:21:23.958 --> 00:21:27.958
and more about a multiplicity of things.

00:21:27.958 --> 00:21:34.958
KA: Before we end, I know you have a piece of digital video

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:37.958
of the experience of being on this platform?

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:40.958
DR: John Kamen -- who's here, actually -- put together

00:21:40.958 --> 00:21:43.958
a two and a half minute piece that shows the platform in use.

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:48.958
So I thought that would be good to end with.

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:04.958
DR: We're looking from Fulton Street, west.

00:22:04.958 --> 00:22:08.958
One of the tricky issues we had with the Giuliani administration

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:11.958
was I had forgotten how anti-graffiti he was.

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:18.958
And essentially our structure was designed to be written on.

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:20.958
KA: As you say, it's not a memorial.

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:22.958
But were you conscious of memorials? The Vietnam Memorial?

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:23.958
Those kinds of forms?

00:22:24.958 --> 00:22:29.958
DR: We certainly did as much research as we could,

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:33.958
and we were conscious of other memorials.

00:22:33.958 --> 00:22:36.958
And also the complexity and length of time they really take to do.

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:40.958
It's 350 people on the committee for Oklahoma City,

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:45.958
which is why we thought of this as a sort of ad-hoc, spontaneous solution

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:48.958
that expanded on Union Square

00:22:48.958 --> 00:22:56.958
and the places that were ad-hoc memorials in the city already.

00:22:56.958 --> 00:23:01.958
The scaffolding you can see built up over the street is de-mountable.

00:23:12.958 --> 00:23:16.958
What's interesting now is the nature of the site has totally changed,

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:18.958
so that what you're aware of

00:23:18.958 --> 00:23:23.958
is not just the destruction of the buildings in Ground Zero,

00:23:23.958 --> 00:23:25.958
but all of the buildings around it --

00:23:25.958 --> 00:23:28.958
and the scars on the building around it, which are enormous.

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:32.958
This shows Saint Paul's on the left.

00:23:37.958 --> 00:23:42.958
KA: I just want to thank you on behalf of New Yorkers

00:23:42.958 --> 00:23:45.958
for making this happen and getting this done.

00:23:45.958 --> 00:23:50.958
But the kind of virtually instantaneous nature of its erection,

00:23:50.958 --> 00:23:53.958
and its being there,

00:23:53.958 --> 00:23:56.958
almost before you could believe

00:23:56.958 --> 00:24:00.958
that a response of this magnitude could be accomplished,

00:24:00.958 --> 00:24:05.958
is part of its extraordinary --

00:24:05.958 --> 00:24:08.958
I don't know if beauty is the word --

00:24:08.958 --> 00:24:11.958
but presence.

00:24:11.958 --> 00:24:13.958
DR: It was an honor to do.

00:24:13.958 --> 00:24:16.958
And we were thrilled to be able to show it here.

title: Let's rethink America's military strategy
transcript: I get asked a lot what the difference between my work is and typical Pentagon long-range strategic planners. And the answer I like to offer is what they typically do is they think about the future of wars in the context of war. And what I've spent 15 years doing in this business — and it's taken me almost 14 to figure it out — is I think about the future of wars in the context of everything else. So I tend to specialize on the scene between war and peace. The material I'm going to show you is one idea from a book with a lot of ideas. It's the one that takes me around the world right now interacting with foreign militaries quite a bit. The material was generated in two years of work I did for the Secretary of Defense, thinking about a new national grand strategy for the United States. I'm going to present a problem and try to give you an answer.Here's my favorite bonehead concept from the 1990s in the Pentagon: the theory of anti-access, area-denial asymmetrical strategies. Why do we call it that? Because it's got all those A's lined up I guess. This is gobbledygook for if the United States fights somebody we're going to be huge. They're going to be small. And if they try to fight us in the traditional, straight-up manner we're going to kick their ass, which is why people don't try to do that any more. I met the last Air Force General who had actually shot down an enemy plane in combat. He's now a one star General. That's how distant we are from even meeting an air force willing to fly against ours. So that overmatched capability creates problems — catastrophic successes the White House calls them.(Laughter)And we're trying to figure that out, because it is an amazing capability. The question is, what's the good you can do with it? OK? The theory of anti-access, area-denial asymmetrical strategies — gobbledygook that we sell to Congress, because if we just told them we can kick anybody's asses they wouldn't buy us all the stuff we want. So we say, area-denial, anti-access asymmetrical strategies and their eyes glaze over.(Laughter)And they say, "Will you build it in my district?"(Laughter)(Applause)Here's my parody and it ain't much of one. Let's talk about a battle space. I don't know, Taiwan Straits 2025. Let's talk about an enemy embedded within that battle space. I don't know, the Million Man Swim.(Laughter)The United States has to access that battle space instantaneously. They throw up anti-access, area-denial asymmetrical strategies. A banana peel on the tarmac.(Laughter)Trojan horses on our computer networks reveal all our Achilles' heels instantly. We say, "China, it's yours." Prometheus approach, largely a geographic definition, focuses almost exclusively on the start of conflict. We field the first-half team in a league that insists on keeping score until the end of the game. That's the problem. We can run the score up against anybody, and then get our asses kicked in the second half — what they call fourth generation warfare.Here's the way I like to describe it instead. There is no battle space the U.S. Military cannot access. They said we couldn't do Afghanistan. We did it with ease. They said we couldn't do Iraq. We did it with 150 combat casualties in six weeks. We did it so fast we weren't prepared for their collapse. There is nobody we can't take down. The question is, what do you do with the power?So there's no trouble accessing battle spaces. What we have trouble accessing is the transition space that must naturally follow, and creating the peace space that allows us to move on. Problem is, the Defense Department over here beats the hell out of you. The State Department over here says, "Come on boy, I know you can make it." And that poor country runs off that ledge, does that cartoon thing and then drops.(Laughter)This is not about overwhelming force, but proportional force. It's about non-lethal technologies, because if you fire real ammo into a crowd of women and children rioting you're going to lose friends very quickly. This is not about projecting power, but about staying power, which is about legitimacy with the locals. Who do you access in this transition space?You have to create internal partners. You have to access coalition partners. We asked the Indians for 17,000 peace keepers. I know their senior leadership, they wanted to give it to us. But they said to us, "You know what? In that transition space you're mostly hat not enough cattle. We don't think you can pull it off, we're not going to give you our 17,000 peace keepers for fodder." We asked the Russians for 40,000. They said no. I was in China in August, I said, "You should have 50,000 peace keepers in Iraq. It's your oil, not ours." Which is the truth. It's their oil. And the Chinese said to me, "Dr. Barnett, you're absolutely right. In a perfect world we'd have 50,000 there. But it's not a perfect world, and your administration isn't getting us any closer." But we have trouble accessing our outcomes.We lucked out, frankly, on the selection. We face different opponents across these three. And it's time to start admitting you can't ask the same 19-year-old to do it all, day in and day out. It's just too damn hard. We have an unparalleled capacity to wage war. We don't do the everything else so well. Frankly, we do it better than anybody and we still suck at it. We have a brilliant Secretary of War. We don't have a Secretary of Everything Else. Because if we did, that guy would be in front of the Senate, still testifying over Abu Ghraib. The problem is he doesn't exist. There is no Secretary of Everything Else. I think we have an unparalleled capacity to wage war. I call that the Leviathan Force. What we need to build is a force for the Everything Else. I call them the System Administrators.What I think this really represents is lack of an A to Z rule set for the world as a whole for processing politically bankrupt states. We have one for processing economically bankrupt states. It's the IMF Sovereign Bankruptcy Plan, OK? We argue about it every time we use it. Argentina just went through it, broke a lot of rules. They got out on the far end, we said, "Fine, don't worry about it." It's transparent. A certain amount of certainty gives the sense of a non-zero outcome. We don't have one for processing politically bankrupt states that, frankly, everybody wants gone. Like Saddam, like Mugabe, like Kim Jong-Il — people who kill in hundreds of thousands or millions. Like the 250,000 dead so far in Sudan.What would an A to Z system look like? I'm going to distinguish between what I call front half and back half. And let's call this red line, I don't know, mission accomplished.(Laughter)(Applause)What we have extant right now, at the beginning of this system, is the U.N. Security Council as a grand jury. What can they do? They can indict your ass. They can debate it. They can write it on a piece of paper. They can put it in an envelope and mail it to you, and then say in no uncertain terms, "Please cut that out."(Laughter)That gets you about four million dead in Central Africa over the 1990s. That gets you 250,000 dead in the Sudan in the last 15 months. Everybody's got to answer their grandchildren some day what you did about the holocaust in Africa, and you better have an answer. We don't have anything to translate that will into action.What we do have is the U.S.-enabled Leviathan Force that says, "You want me to take that guy down? I'll take that guy down. I'll do it on Tuesday. It will cost you 20 billion dollars."(Laughter)But here's the deal. As soon as I can't find anybody else to air out, I leave the scene immediately. That's called the Powell Doctrine. Way downstream we have the International Criminal Court. They love to put them on trial. They've got Milosević right now.What are we missing? A functioning executive that will translate will into action, because we don't have it. Every time we lead one of these efforts we have to whip ourselves into this imminent threat thing. We haven't faced an imminent threat since the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. But we use this language from a bygone era to scare ourselves into doing something because we're a democracy and that's what it takes. And if that doesn't work we scream, "He's got a gun!" just as we rush in.(Laughter)And then we look over the body and we find an old cigarette lighter and we say, "Jesus, it was dark."(Laughter)Do you want to do it, France? France says, "No, but I do like to criticize you after the fact."What we need downstream is a great power enabled — what I call that Sys Admin Force. We should have had 250,000 troops streaming into Iraq on the heels of that Leviathan sweeping towards Baghdad. What do you get then? No looting, no military disappearing, no arms disappearing, no ammo disappearing, no Muqtada Al-Sadr — I'm wrecking his bones — no insurgency. Talk to anybody who was over there in the first six months. We had six months to feel the lob, to get the job done, and we dicked around for six months. And then they turned on us. Why? Because they just got fed up. They saw what we did to Saddam. They said, "You're that powerful, you can resurrect this country. You're America."What we need is an international reconstruction fund — Sebastian Mallaby, Washington Post, great idea. Model on the IMF. Instead of passing the hat each time, OK? Where are we going to find this guy? G20, that's easy. Check out their agenda since 9/11. All security dominated. They're going to decide up front how the money gets spent just like in the IMF. You vote according to how much money you put in the kitty. Here's my challenge to the Defense Department. You've got to build this force. You've got to seed this force. You've got to track coalition partners. Create a record of success. You will get this model. You tell me it's too hard to do. I'll walk this dog right through that six part series on the Balkans. We did it just like that. I'm talking about regularizing it, making it transparent. Would you like Mugabe gone? Would you like Kim Jong-Il, who's killed about two million people, would you like him gone? Would you like a better system? This is why it matters to the military. They've been experiencing an identity crisis since the end of the Cold War. I'm not talking about the difference between reality and desire, which I can do because I'm not inside the beltway.(Laughter)I'm talking about the 1990s. The Berlin Wall falls. We do Desert Storm. The split starts to emerge between those in the military who see a future they can live with, and those who see a future that starts to scare them, like the U.S. submarine community, which watches the Soviet Navy disappear overnight. Ah!(Laughter)So they start moving from reality towards desire and they create their own special language to describe their voyage of self-discovery and self-actualization.(Laughter)The problem is you need a big, sexy opponent to fight against. And if you can't find one you've got to make one up. China, all grown up, going to be a looker!(Laughter)The rest of the military got dragged down into the muck across the 1990s and they developed this very derisive term to describe it: military operations other than war. I ask you, who joins the military to do things other than war? Actually, most of them. Jessica Lynch never planned on shooting back. Most of them don't pick up a rifle. I maintain this is code inside the Army for, "We don't want to do this." They spent the 1990s working the messy scene between globalized parts of the world What I call the core and the gap. The Clinton administration wasn't interested in running this. For eight years, after screwing up the relationship on day one — inauguration day with gays in the military — which was deft.(Laughter)So we were home alone for eight years. And what did we do home alone? We bought one military and we operated another. It's like the guy who goes to the doctor and says, "Doctor, it hurts when I do this."(Laughter)The doctor says, "Stop doing that you idiot."I used to give this brief inside the Pentagon in the early 1990s. I'd say, "You're buying one military and you're operating another, and eventually it's going to hurt. It's wrong. Bad Pentagon, bad!"(Laughter)And they'd say, "Dr. Barnett, you are so right. Can you come back next year and remind us again?"(Laughter)Some people say 9/11 heals the rift — jerks the long-term transformation gurus out of their 30,000 foot view of history, drags them down in to the muck and says, "You want a networked opponent? I've got one, he's everywhere, go find him." It elevates MOOTW — how we pronounce that acronym — from crap to grand strategy, because that's how you're going to shrink that gap.Some people put these two things together and they call it empire, which I think is a boneheaded concept. Empire is about the enforcement of not just minimal rule sets, which you cannot do, but maximum rule sets which you must do. It's not our system of governance. Never how we've sought to interact with the outside world. I prefer that phrase System Administration. We enforce the minimal rule sets for maintaining connectivity to the global economy. Certain bad things you cannot do. How this impacts the way we think about the future of war. This is a concept which gets me vilified throughout the Pentagon. It makes me very popular as well. Everybody's got an opinion.Going back to the beginning of our country — historically, defenses meant protection of the homeland. Security has meant everything else. Written into our constitution, two different forces, two different functions. Raise an army when you need it, and maintain a navy for day-to-day connectivity. A Department of War, a Department of Everything Else. A big stick, a baton stick. Can of whup ass, the networking force. In 1947 we merged these two things together in the Defense Department. Our long-term rationale becomes, we're involved in a hair trigger stand off with the Soviets. To attack America is to risk blowing up the world. We connected national security to international security with about a seven minute time delay. That's not our problem now. They can kill three million in Chicago tomorrow and we don't go to the mattresses with nukes. That's the scary part.The question is how do we reconnect American national security with global security to make the world a lot more comfortable, and to embed and contextualize our employment of force around the planet? What's happened since is that bifurcation I described. We talked about this going all the way back to the end of the Cold War. Let's have a Department of War, and a Department of Something Else. Some people say, "Hell, 9/11 did it for you." Now we've got a home game and an away game.(Laughter)The Department of Homeland Security is a strategic feel good measure. It's going to be the Department of Agriculture for the 21st century. TSA — thousands standing around.(Laughter)I supported the war in Iraq. He was a bad guy with multiple priors. It's not like we had to find him actually killing somebody live to arrest him. I knew we'd kick ass in the war with the Leviathan Force. I knew we'd have a hard time with what followed. But I know this organization doesn't change until it experiences failure. What do I mean by these two different forces?This is the Hobbesian Force. I love this force. I don't want to see it go. That plus nukes rules out great power war. This is the military the rest of the world wants us to build. It's why I travel all over the world talking to foreign militaries.What does this mean? It means you've got to stop pretending you can do these two very disparate skill sets with the same 19-year-old. Switching back, morning, afternoon, evening, morning, afternoon, evening. Handing out aid, shooting back, handing out aid, shooting back. It's too much. The 19-year-olds get tired from the switching, OK?(Laughter)That force on the left, you can train a 19-year-old to do that. That force on the right is more like a 40-year-old cop. You need the experience. What does this mean in terms of operations?The rule is going to be this. That Sys Admin force is the force that never comes home, does most of your work. You break out that Leviathan Force only every so often. But here's the promise you make to the American public, to your own people, to the world. You break out that Leviathan Force, you promise, you guarantee that you're going to mount one hell of a — immediately — follow-on Sys Admin effort. Don't plan for the war unless you plan to win the peace.(Applause)Other differences. Leviathan traditional partners, they all look like the Brits and their former colonies.(Laughter)Including us, I would remind you. The rest — wider array of partners. International organizations, non-governmental organizations, private voluntary organizations, contractors. You're not going to get away from that. Leviathan Force, it's all about joint operations between the military services. We're done with that. What we need to do is inter-agency operations, which frankly Condi Rice was in charge of. And I'm amazed nobody asked her that question when she was confirmed.I call the Leviathan Force your dad's military. I like them young, male, unmarried, slightly pissed off.(Laughter)I call the Sys Admin Force your mom's military. It's everything the man's military hates. Gender balanced much more, older, educated, married with children. The force on the left, up or out. The force on the right, in and out. The force on the left respects Posse Comitatus restrictions on the use of force inside the U.S. The force on the right's going to obliterate it. That's where the National Guard's going to be. The force on the left is never coming under the purview of the International Criminal Court. Sys Admin Force has to. Different definitions of network centricity. One takes down networks, one puts them up. And you've got to wage war here in such a way to facilitate that.Do we need a bigger budget? Do we need a draft to pull this off? Absolutely not. I've been told by the Revolution of Military Affairs crowd for years, we can do it faster, cheaper, smaller, just as lethal. I say, "Great, I'm going to take the Sys Admin budget out of your hide."Here's the larger point. You're going to build the Sys Admin Force inside the U.S. Military first. But ultimately you're going to civilianize it, probably two thirds. Inter agency-ize it, internationalize it. So yes, it begins inside the Pentagon, but over time it's going to cross that river.(Laughter)I have been to the mountain top. I can see the future. I may not live long enough to get you there, but it's going to happen. We're going to have a Department of Something Else between war and peace.Last slide. Who gets custody of the kids? This is where the Marines in the audience get kind of tense. (Laughter) And this is when they think about beating the crap out of me after the talk.(Laughter)Read Max Boon. This is the history of the marines — small wars, small arms. The Marines are like my West Highland Terrier. They get up every morning, they want to dig a hole and they want to kill something.(Laughter)I don't want my Marines handing out aid. I want them to be Marines. That's what keeps the Sys Admin Force from being a pussy force. It keeps it from being the U.N. You shoot at these people the Marines are going to come over and kill you.(Laughter)(Applause)Department of Navy, strategic subs go this way, surface combatants are over there, and the news is they may actually be that small.(Laughter)I call it the Smart Dust Navy. I tell young officers, "You may command 500 ships in your career. Bad news is they may not have anybody on them." Carriers go both ways because they're a swing asset. You'll see the pattern — airborne, just like carriers. Armor goes this way. Here's the dirty secret of the Air Force, you can win by bombing. But you need lots of these guys on the ground to win the peace. Shinseki was right with the argument. Air force, strategic airlift goes both ways. Bombers, fighters go over here. Special Operations Command down at Tampa. Trigger-pullers go this way. Civil Affairs, that bastard child, comes over here. Return to the Army. The point about the trigger-pullers and Special Operations Command. No off season, these guys are always active. They drop in, do their business, disappear. See me now. Don't talk about it later.(Laughter)I was never here.(Laughter)The world is my playground.(Laughter)I want to keep trigger-pullers trigger-happy. I want the rules to be as loose as possible. Because when the thing gets prevented in Chicago with the three million dead that perverts our political system beyond all recognition, these are the guys who are going to kill them first. So it's better off to have them make some mistakes along the way than to see that.Reserve component — National Guard reserves overwhelmingly Sys Admin. How are you going to get them to work for this force? Most firemen in this country do it for free. This is not about money. This is about being up front with these guys and gals.Last point, intelligence community — the muscle and the defense agencies go this way. What should be the CIA, open, analytical, open source should come over here. The information you need to do this is not secret. It's not secret. Read that great piece in the New Yorker about how our echo boomers, 19 to 25, over in Iraq taught each other how to do Sys Admin work, over the Internet in chat rooms. They said, "Al Qaeda could be listening." They said, "Well, Jesus, they already know this stuff."(Laughter)Take a gift in the left hand. These are the sunglasses that don't scare people, simple stuff. Censors and transparency, the overheads go in both directions.Thanks.
